content: How can I help you today?

I'm not sure, honestly. My wife pushed me to come here, but I'm not convinced this will help. Things at home are just really overwhelming right now, and I don’t know if talking about it will change much.

It sounds like things feel pretty overwhelming for you right now, and maybe you're unsure if this session could make a difference. Having your wife encourage you to come here might add to the pressure you're already feeling. What’s been going on at home lately that’s making everything so overwhelming?

Well, my son has been acting out a lot, and my wife and I can’t seem to figure out how to help him. It’s starting to put a strain on our marriage, and I feel like we’re just drifting apart. Between that stress and constantly worrying about what to do for him, I can’t focus on work or enjoy anything anymore. It’s like everything’s falling apart.

That sounds like a lot to carry all at once—trying to support your son, navigating stress in your marriage, and feeling drained in other parts of your life, too. It's understandable why you're feeling like things are slipping out of control. How have you been coping with all of this?

Honestly, I'm not sure if I have been. I feel like I'm just going through the motions every day, trying to keep things together, but it's not working. Most days, I just feel defeated and stuck, like there's no way to fix any of it.

It sounds like you're in a tough place right now, feeling stuck and like nothing you try is making a difference. Facing so much at once—your son's behavior, challenges in your marriage, and your own feelings of defeat—can be exhausting. Even though all of this feels overwhelming, the fact that you're here thinking through it shows strength. What would be different for you if you didn’t feel so stuck?

I guess if I didn’t feel so stuck, I’d feel more like myself again. Like I could actually be present for my wife and my kids, instead of just feeling like I’m failing them. Maybe I’d even find time to enjoy things again. But right now, it’s hard to even imagine getting there.

You're longing to reconnect—not just with your wife and kids, but also with yourself and the things that bring you joy. It sounds like that means a lot to you, even if imagining it feels far off right now. Despite how hard things are, you've been thinking about what getting "unstuck" might look like. What do you think would need to happen for you to take that step toward feeling more like yourself again?

You’d have to help my son somehow—or I’d have to figure out what’s going on with him and how to deal with it. That feels like the biggest mountain right now, and everything else is tied to that. But I’ve tried so hard already, and I don’t even know where to start anymore.

It sounds like your son’s struggles are weighing heavily on you, and figuring out how to help him feels like a monumental challenge. You’ve really been trying, but not knowing where to start anymore has left you feeling defeated. If you could take even one small step toward understanding or addressing what’s going on with him, what do you think that might look like?

Sorry, I just... I don’t even know what that step would be. It feels like we’ve tried everything—talking to him, setting boundaries, being supportive—and nothing works. Maybe we need outside help, but I don’t know if that’ll make any difference either.

It’s clear how much you’ve already poured into trying to help your son in every way you can, and feeling like nothing has worked must be frustrating and disheartening. The idea of seeking outside help feels uncertain for you right now—after trying so much on your own, it’s hard to imagine another approach making a difference. What would it take for you to feel ready to explore that possibility further?

I think it would take knowing that outside help could actually make a difference. I’m skeptical because I feel like no one understands what we’re dealing with, or they’ll just tell us things we already know. But I guess if it could really help my son—and maybe take some of the pressure off us as parents—it might be worth a shot.

It’s understandable to feel skeptical, especially when it seems like no one could fully grasp what you’re going through or offer anything new. Yet, you’re considering that if outside help could genuinely make a difference for your son and ease some of the weight on you and your wife, it might be worth exploring. It sounds like you deeply care about finding support that would truly benefit your family. Is there anything that could make you feel more confident about taking that step?

I think if I could find someone who really listens and actually has experience helping families like mine, it might give me a little more confidence. Maybe knowing there’s a clear plan or approach that we haven’t tried yet would help too. Right now, I just feel like it’s hard to trust that anyone could offer something different.

Wanting someone who truly listens, understands, and brings new insight feels really important to you—and it makes sense that trust is hard to build after everything you’ve been through. The idea of a clear plan or a fresh approach might help you feel more confident about reaching out for outside support. You’ve already shown courage in considering this step and sharing your concerns. Would you like to talk more about what it could look like to explore resources or support together?
I think I am okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
